Remember to view a matrix as a transformation between two spaces.
$image(A) = span(u_1, u_2, \dots, u_n)$ looking at the column vectors
Not necessarily a basis (not necessarily linearly independent), but definitely the a span

Can only solve $Ax = b$ if $b \in image(A)$

So we find a basis to make things easier

We can also look at the row space ($v_1, v_2, \dots, v_n$)
Or we look at $A^T$ and look at the old rows as columns (and the transpose, the adjoint, maps in the opposite the direction)

We can identify the redundancies by row reducing $A$ and $A^T$, OR
we can row reduce $A$ with the identity matrix on the right (like computing the inverse). Keep track of the row operations.
Then we can pull out the row operations that generate the the equivalent rows.

The ones that equal $0$ help you identify linear dependencies, which allows you to identify redundancies and further pull out a span for the row space.

The augmented side will basically be in lower triangular form

Column and Row space have same number of basis vectors

Swapping makes things messy

$S$ is a subspace of $D^n$ where $D$ is some vector space
$S = span(u_1, u_2, \dots, u_m), m \leq n$
$S$ is a subset of $D^n$ that acts like a space on its own

Rule: Every subspace $\in \mathbb{R}^n$ has a basis (i.e., is a span of vectors)

Unique number of basis vectors that spans the subspace, and that defines the dimension

$rank(A) :=$ dimension of row/column space
$rank(A) :=$ is number of leading 1s (pivot)
$nullity(A) :=$ dimension of null space of $A$

$rank(A) + nullity(A) = cols(A)$, since the free variables in $rref(A)$ show up in the span of $ker(T) = null(A)$
